intro: Rhamnus punctata var. angustifolia, commonly known as the narrow-leaf buckthorn, is a shrub native to parts of Asia and the Pacific Islands. It typically grows to a height of 1–3 meters and has slender, often thorned branches. The leaves are alternate, ovate to elliptic, and have a distinctive yellowish-green underside. It produces small, greenish-yellow flowers in clusters, followed by dark blue berries that are edible for birds. This species is adapted to a variety of soil types and thrives in full sun to partial shade.
